","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Casteism ","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"is discriminating on the basis of these hierarchically stratified social categories. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The caste system originating from the Hindu tradition in India is often glossed over as a mere division of labor, and hence not of much relevance in today's economically mobile globalized world. However, the reality is that caste is a rigid hierarchical socioeconomic stratification of society with related taboos and religious undertones having practical implications in maintaining and perpetuating a grossly unequal power structure in society. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The social hierarchy of the caste system is comprised of four castes of which the first three castes are considered the \"upper castes\" and the fourth caste is the \"lower caste\". The highest and most powerful caste in this social hierarchy is the Brahmin (priestly) caste. The caste system is the only known social stratification where, in addition to named groups, a sub-section of society is officially outcasted and considered ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\"untouchable\"","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" (now referred to as ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Dalit","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" - calling or thinking of someone as","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\"untouchable\" ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"is unacceptable, and the creators of this site unequivocally condemn perceiving or addressing any individual, group or community as ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\"untouchable\" ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"- usage of the term on this website is mindful and deliberate, only to bring home the unacceptable, discriminatory nature of the caste system & expose the reality of millions, and is meant without any disrespect)","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Ironically ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Dalit","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" are the unofficial fifth caste, ironically because they are officially considered to be casteless outcasts, and hence outside the caste system. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The uniqueness of the caste system - which in turns explains the inherent discriminatory nature of the system - is that, the sheer accident of birth determines whether one has the privileged life of an upper caste or whether one is condemned to a life of degradation, humiliation and oppression of a lower caste, or even worse, an outcast not belonging to any caste and hence an ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\"untouchable\" ","marks":[{"type":"italic"},{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"(","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Dalit","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" ). The term ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Dalit","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" means \"broken\", split, oppressed, and is the chosen preferred term of self-identification by the community that was labelled ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\"untouchable\"","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"  within the caste system. ","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"It is true that today there are legal ramifications associated with the caste system, in that, according to the Indian Constitution it is illegal to discriminate on the basis of caste. It is also true that there are affirmative action programs aimed to address the historical systemic discrimination of the lower castes and outcasts. However, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"as noted by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar,","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" Chairman of the Drafting Committee of the Indian Constitution, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"\"Caste is a notion; it is a state of the mind.”","marks":[{"type":"bold"},{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" [Annihilation of Caste, 1936]","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Justified as having divine origins, this \"notion\", this \"state of mind\" filled with taboos and rituals that have been ingrained in society over centuries and internalized by both, the privileged oppressors and the oppressed, has been the biggest hurdle in dispelling the ills of the caste system. When young he was denied same access to education as the upper caste students. In spite of overcoming odds encountered at every turn in life, the stigma of caste and/or being an \"outcast\", and the oppression that accompanies that stigma, does not leave them, begging him to come to the conclusion that \"the question (problem set) posed by caste is much more difficult to answer than a math questions (problem sets)\". The film revolves around the conflicted relationship between marginalized Bharati, a Dalit factory floor worker, and priviliged Priya, a Brahmin who lands Bharati's dream desk job of a data operator in the same factory. As a friendship develops between them, both women are attracted to each other. In ensuing interactions between Priya and Bharati we see delicate balance between love and betrayal, the conflicted relationship between acceptance of one's sexuality on the one hand and the barrier of caste on the other, where eventually casteism wins the day.
